title.value: Sensory salience processing moderates attenuated gazes on faces in autism spectrum disorder: a case–control study
title.justification: This is the title of the provided research paper.
title.quote: Sensory salience processing moderates attenuated gazes on faces in autism spectrum disorder: a case–control study

extractions.description: This paper investigates the role of sensory salience processing (SSP) in modulating visual attention towards faces in individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) using baseline eye-tracking data from the EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP). It specifically examines the possible impact of LC-NE (locus coeruleus-norepinephrine) system functioning on SSP and its association with social attention in ASD.

type.justification: The paper includes systematic collection and analysis of eye-tracking and pupillometry data to assess sensory salience processing and social attention in individuals with ASD compared to neurotypical individuals.
type.quote: We tested the hypothesis that altered LC-NE functioning contributes to different SSP and results in diverging social attention in ASD. Methods We analyzed the baseline eye-tracking data of the EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP).

name.justification: The paper utilizes computer vision approaches to generate saliency maps which are essential for studying sensory salience processing.
name.quote: The sensory salience of stimuli can be quantified by using computer vision approaches that aim to reconstruct human sensory processing in the visual cortex.

name.justification: The study focuses on Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and investigates sensory salience processing and social attention within this context.
name.quote: Background Attenuated social attention is a key marker of autism spectrum disorder (ASD).

name.justification: The role of the LC-NE system in modulating sensory salience processing and visual attention is a significant part of the study, linking it to the field of Neuroscience.
name.quote: The locus coeruleus–norepinephrine system (LC-NE) has been established as a modulator of this sensory salience processing (SSP).

name.justification: Methodologically, the paper heavily relies on eye-tracking data to study visual attention.
name.quote: The study assesses autistic individuals compared to neurotypical controls during the visual exploration of video scenes with humans and without humans. We estimate SSP by (1) pupillary responses as an index of LC-NE phasic activity and (2) gaze analysis of computer-generated saliency maps for sensory salience.

name.justification: The paper explicitly mentions the use of baseline eye-tracking data from the EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP) for its analysis.
name.quote: Methods We analyzed the baseline eye-tracking data of the EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP)

referenced_paper_title.value: The EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP): clinical characterisation
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the referenced paper that describes the dataset used in the study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The sample is a subsample of the project “European Autism Interventions—A Multicentre Study for Developing New Medications (EU-AIMS) Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP) study” [62].

name.justification: The paper uses the OpenCV library for extracting physical and motion salience information in its analysis.
name.quote: We applied the open-source computer vision library (OpenCV 4.4.0) by custom python scripts (version 3.8) [70] to extract physical and motion salience information.

referenced_paper_title.justification: OpenCV is the library mentioned for computer vision tasks in the study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We applied the open-source computer vision library (OpenCV 4.4.0) by custom python scripts (version 3.8) [70] to extract physical and motion salience information.
